column1: The prime ministers of India and Japan met in Tokyo.

India's new prime minister, Narendra Modi, is meeting his Japanese counterpart, Shinzo Abe, in Tokyo to discuss economic and security ties in his first major foreign visit since his election victory in May.
Mr Modi is on a five-day trip to Japan to cement economic ties with the world's third-largest economy.
Plans for greater nuclear cooperation are high on the agenda.
India is also reportedly hoping for a defence cooperation treaty between the two nations.
Karratha police arrest 20-year-old after fast motorcycle chase
A motorcycle has been impounded after the rider drove it at 125km / h in a 70km / h zone and through bushland to escape police in Bilbara.
Traffic police in Karratha attempted to stop a blue motorcycle this morning after watching it leave a petrol station on Bathgate Road at 125km / h.
Police say the driver then ignored the stop signals and continued on Burgess Road before turning into bushland, where officers lost sight of it.
The motorcycle and a person matching the description of the rider were later seen at a house in Walcott Way in Bulgarra.
Karratha police have charged a 20-year-old man with failing to obey a stop sign and reckless driving.
He is due to appear at Karratha Local Court on September 23.
The motorcycle was seized and impounded for three months.
George Webster charged with hotel rapes in Naim and Pitlochry
A man is on trial for raping women at two hotels.
George Webster, 28, was read the charges at a hearing at the High Court in Glasgow.
He is accused of raping a woman at Scotland's Hotel in Pitlochry, Perthshire, on 7 June 2013.
The indictment alleges that Webster assaulted her while she was "unconscious, asleep, and unable to signal consent."
Webster is also accused of raping a second woman at the Golf View Hotel in Naim in the Scottish Highlands on May 4, 2014.
Judge Lady Rae set the trial date for November 17 at the High Court in Edinburgh.
Returning to the very American ideal of labor rights as human rights
Congressmen Keith Ellison and John Lewis have introduced a bill to make union organizing a civil right.
As unions die, so do middle-class jobs, said Ellison, a Democrat from Minnesota and vice chairman of the Congressional Progressive Caucus.
That's why I'm proud to join civil rights icon John Lewis in introducing the Employee Empowerment Act.
This ground-breaking law gives workers the same legal options for discrimination for organizing unions as for other forms of discrimination - and thus stops anti-union forces.

Amending the national labor law to create a way for workers exposed to discrimination to organize union representation, to seek justice in a civil court - and to obtain damages or fines - is a sensible and necessary initiative.
But it is certainly not a radical initiative - at least not by American standards.
Indeed, the best way to understand what Ellison, Lewis, and the other sponsors of their bill are proposing is to link back to a very American idea.

Despite the setbacks that unions have faced in recent years - in Wisconsin, Michigan, and other states across the country - Americans once encouraged countries around the world to recognize, expand, and uphold labor rights.
There was a time, which millions of Americans still remember, when this country called democracy, freedom of speech, freedom of the press and the right of association in the same breath.

When the United States occupied Japan after World War II, General Douglas Mac Arthur and his staff encouraged the country to adopt a constitution to ensure that the militarized autocracy of Hedki Tojo would be replaced by democracy.

Fully aware that workers and their unions had a role to play in creating a new Japan, they used language that explicitly recognized that "workers" rights to unification and collective bargaining and action are guaranteed. "

When the United States occupied Germany after World War II, General Dwight David Eisenhower and his staff urged the Germans to write a constitution that would ensure that Adolf Hitler's fascism was replaced by a strong democracy.

Recognizing that the workers would have to organize and raise their voices in the new nation, the Germans inserted a clause that explicitly stated: "The right to form associations to safeguard and improve labor and economic conditions is guaranteed to every individual and every profession or trade.
Agreements that restrict this right or seek to diminish it are null and void; measures aimed at it are illegal.

When former First Lady Eleanor Roosevelt chaired the International Commission on Human Rights, which drafted the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, adopted by the United Nations as a global treaty in 1948, Roosevelt and the other authors included a guarantee that "everyone has the right to form or join trade unions to protect their interests."
For generations, Americans have accepted the basic premise that labor rights are human rights.

When that country was advising other countries on how to form civil and democratic societies, Americans declared that the right to form a union - and to have that union participate in collective bargaining as an equal partner with companies and government agencies - must be protected.

After these rights have come under attack in America, it is indeed very wise to reaffirm the American ideal that working people must have the right to unite and make themselves heard in a free and open society.
As the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. said fifty years ago:
History is a great teacher.
Now everyone knows that the labor movement did not limit the strength of the nation, but increased it.
By raising the living standards of millions of people, labor has miraculously created a market for industry and raised the entire nation to unimaginable levels of production.
Those who attack labor forget these simple truths, but history preserves them.
History remembers, and so should we.

Formal recognition of labour rights as human rights - and the extension of the protection of civil rights as protection against discrimination in the creation of employee representation - is long overdue.
Keith Ellison and John Lewis are renewing the ideals that made America great in the past and delivered on the promise of democracy.
Judge temporarily halts law that could force all abortion clinics in Louisiana to close
A US federal judge on Sunday temporarily halted implementation of a law in Louisiana that lawyers say would have likely led to the closure of all five abortion clinics in the state.

The measure, made law by Louisiana Governor Bobby Jindal in June and set to take effect on Sept. 1, would force doctors who perform abortions to purchase a patient admission right at a hospital within a 30-mile radius of their practice.
However, the judge's decision means doctors can continue to perform legal abortions for the time being while they apply for such a right.
Plaintiffs may continue to work in accordance with the law while seeking to obtain these rights, federal Judge John deGravelles wrote in his ruling.
A hearing for the judge is scheduled within a month to make the law more permanent.
Abortion advocates welcomed the decision, the latest in a series of rulings against similar measures, saying it would give doctors more time to gain hospital admission rights.

Today's decision means that Louisiana women are escaping a sneaky law that seeks to take away their health and rights, said Nancy Northup, president and chief executive of the Center for Reproductive Rights, which sued on behalf of three of the state's five clinics to stop the law.
It was not immediately clear whether the ruling also extended to doctors from the two clinics who had not joined the lawsuit and had also applied for referral rights.
Louisiana is one of 11 states that have passed similar laws, with courts recently declaring such measures unconstitutional in Alabama and Mississippi.
Key parts of a Texas law that would have forced most of the state's remaining clinics to close were halted by a federal judge on Friday.
Abortion advocates and the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists and the American Medical Association agree that referral rights require unnecessary restrictions on doctors.
Abortion opponents counter that the measures are designed to protect women's health, although some also welcomed the impact of closing clinics.
Only one doctor performing abortions in Louisiana has patient referral rights, the Center for Reproductive Rights said.
If all other doctors in the state were forced to stop performing abortions, that doctor would not perform the surgery for fear of his safety, the group said.
In arguing against the ruling, Louisiana officials said they would not punish doctors for performing abortions while their applications for patient referral rights were pending.
Delayed diagnoses and lack of access to the best treatments lead to higher death rates from ovarian cancer in rural areas.
Angelina Jolie and her brother James have posted a video tribute to their mother, who died of ovarian cancer in 2007.
Women in rural Australia are at a higher risk of dying from ovarian cancer than urban women.
Researchers analysed medical data from more than 1100 Australians diagnosed with ovarian cancer in 2005 and found only 25 per cent were still alive five years after diagnosis.

Research leader Susan Jordan of the QIMR Berghofer Medical Research Institute said those living in rural and remote areas of the state were 20 percent more likely to die during the study than those living in urban areas.
SMALL STUDY: New drugs could slow lung and ovarian cancer
The researchers examined the women's medical care over seven years.
Dr Jordan said a woman's age at diagnosis, type of ovarian cancer, pre-existing conditions and social and economic status also affected her chances of survival.
Survival rates were lowest for older women and those whose cancer was more advanced at the time of diagnosis.
Those living in rural and remote areas of the state were 20 percent more likely to die during the study than those living in urban areas.

Although the study did not examine why out-of-town women were more likely to die from ovarian cancer, Dr. Jordan suspects delayed diagnosis and lack of access to the best treatment centers as possible factors.
This disease is best treated by gynaecological oncologists, and these are mostly found in larger cities, she said.

Despite improving telemedicine services to counter the distances, she suggested as a possible remedy an increase in the service of flown-in doctors to allow specialists to care for women closer to where they live, as well as treatment programs for people outside their region.
Dr Jordan said the study showed poor long-term survival rates in women with ovarian cancer regardless of geographical status and highlighted the need for better treatment and screening strategies.
The study, funded by Rio Tinto Ride to Conquer Cancer, is published today in the Medical Journal of Australia.
In March 2013, Elisha Neave, a 33-year-old mother from the Gold Coast, learned she had an aggressive form of ovarian cancer.
Garden centres lament falling homeowner numbers

The fall, combined with a sharp fall in the number of homeowners under 35, could see garden centres lose tens of thousands of pounds a year if today's young consumers reach the "core age group for garden products," according to a study by the HTA, as reported in the Financial Times.
The report says tenants spend an average of 55 per cent of the amount people with homes spend on their garden.

The rise of people living in highly urbanized areas without gardens, the popular method of paving front gardens for parking purposes and the decline in garden size are other factors threatening the industry, which is worth an estimated £5 billion a year in sales.
Greater London, where the proportion of homeowners has fallen from 61 per cent to 43 per cent over a six-year period, reports the lowest spending on garden products per household.
The HTA and the Royal Horticultural Society point out that housing for rent or small gardens do not mean people cannot grow plants.
Guy Barter, chief horticultural adviser for the RHS, said: 'Container gardening is very popular with tenants, for example, because they can take their plants with them when they move.'
The HTA report identified the period from 1997 to 2005 as the "golden age" of garden retailing due to rising homeownership and economic prosperity from the late 1980s to the mid-1990s.
He also predicted an improved market situation this year due to better weather following unfavourable weather conditions in March and April last year.
The protest movement in Pakistan, led by opposition politician Imran Khan and cleric Tahirul Qadri, continues.
In the capital, Islamabad, about 1,000 demonstrators stormed the state-run television station PTV.
Information Minister Pervaiz Rashid said soldiers had been able to push the protesters out of PTV buildings.
The station stopped broadcasting for about 40 minutes, but has since resumed broadcasting.
At the same time, some 3,000 protesters tried to get to Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif's residence.
About a kilometre away, armed with sticks and stones, they clashed with security forces.
Police used tear gas.
The demonstrators demanded Sharif's resignation, but he refused.
The country's army, meanwhile, is calling for a political solution to the conflict "without wasting time and without using force."
After a meeting at headquarters on Sunday evening, the military said: "The army remains committed to its role of ensuring the security of the state."
The military plays an important role in Pakistan and has already staged more coups.
Opposition politician Imran Khan accuses Prime Minister Sharif of cheating in last May's parliamentary election.
Protests escalated over the weekend after Khan and Qadri called on their supporters to march on Sharif's residence.
Three people were killed.
Turkey summons US diplomat over spy report
Turkey's foreign ministry has summoned the country's longest-serving US diplomat to investigate a report on American and British spying in Turkey.
Deputy Prime Minister Bulent said the chargé d'affaires of the U.S. Embassy and Turkish officials had discussed the report on Monday.

The German magazine Der Spiegel as well as the online magazine The Intercept reported that those of former US National Security Agency analyst Edward Snowden show that Turkey was a major area of activity for the US and British intelligence services.
Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan downplayed the importance of the report, saying all major countries were spying on each other, according to Turkish news agencies.
An earlier report that Germany's main intelligence agency was also targeting Ankara provoked a much more angry reaction from the Turkish government.
Warning strike: Train drivers threaten consequences for commuters
The nationwide warning strike by train drivers on Monday evening could also affect passenger transport in NRW.
The stoppage, announced for 6 to 9 p.m., affects all transport companies nationwide, including long-distance, regional and suburban rail services,
The main thrust of the warning strike is freight transport.

said Sven Schmitte, district chairman of the German Locomotive Drivers "Union (GDL) in Düsseldorf.
We expect significant outages.
There are no regional priorities.
The main thrust of the warning strike is freight transport.
Deutsche Bahn in North Rhine-Westphalia announced that it would do everything possible to minimise the impact.
GDL, however, has not said where it intends to strike, making it difficult to predict the consequences in concrete terms.
Magaluf police chief accused of corruption
Prosecutors presented evidence of extortion by police officers and employees of the city of Calvià to the Majorca Public Prosecutor's Office on Friday.

The head of the Calvià police force on the holiday island of Majorca has been arrested following allegations of corruption by businessmen and bar owners in the notorious binge-drinking hotspot Magaluf.

Chief Commissioner José Antonio Navarro has been remanded in custody following corruption allegations against him by several businessmen from Punta Ballena, the street where most of Magaluf's bars and nightclubs are located.

According to the online daily Mallorca Diario, prosecutors presented evidence of extortion by police officers and employees of the city of Calvià to the Majorcan anti-corruption prosecutor's office on Friday.
Two other local police officers have been arrested by the Spanish Civil Guard in connection with the corruption allegations and are being questioned by a judge along with Navarro.
Spain's national daily ABC reported that the disgruntled nightclub owners said the nepotism of the authorities was having a serious impact on their business.
It's not about making money any more, it's about survival, one of the businessmen told the court.
Leave our livelihoods out of the game.
We have nothing to lose.
Magaluf made international headlines this summer after a viral YouTube video showed an 18-year-old British tourist performing fellatio on 24 men during a booze-fuelled trip.
Island authorities have since tried to stop the disorderly behaviour of alcoholic holidaymakers in Magaluf by minimising the number of people taking part in the notorious alcohol-fuelled pub crawls.
The Playhouse Club where the Fellatio incident took place has been forced to close for a year, while Playhouse and pub tour organiser Carnage face a combined €55,000 ($73,000) fine.

The tourist resort of Magaluf, which is popular with young British holidaymakers, is also known for a number of alcohol-related accidents, including the trend of "balconing," in which people jump from one balcony to another or from a balcony into the hotel pool.
First day of spring with wet and stormy weather affecting flights from Adelaide Airport
SPRING has brought a wintry surprise to South Australia, with heavy showers and strong winds affecting flights from Adelaide Airport.
By 9pm, another 5mm of rain had fallen on the city, after 6.6mm had already fallen on Sunday night.
The latest rainfall was the result of a series of short, stormy showers, including a downpour that began just before 8pm and brought nearly 4mm of rain in about 10 minutes.
After winter provided an early dose of spring last week, temperatures in the city fell back to a high of just 15.8C on Monday.
The gusty weather conditions are believed to have led to the delayed landing of a Virgin Airlines flight from Melbourne to Adelaide.
The plane was due to land shortly after 7.30pm but was hit by a shear wind - a sudden change in wind speed or direction over a short distance - and had to take off.
Wind gusts reached about 50km / h on the ground at Adelaide Airport at the time.
The flight data showed that the plane also had to take off on a second approach and finally touched down at around 8.40pm.
The flight delay led to the delay of several other flights, including an Emirates flight from Dubai and a Quantas flight from Sydney.
A maximum temperature of 16C is forecast for Adelaide on Tuesday, with possible showers.

Israeli children return to their schools after war in Gaza

Thousands of Israeli children from areas near the Gaza Strip returned to schools on Monday after spending the summer in air-raid shelters as rocket and mortar fire rained down on their communities during the 50-day war between Israel and Hamas, and schools in Gaza remained closed while the area recovered from the fighting.
The start of school brought a sense of joy and anticipation to communities in southern Israel scarred by rocket bullet holes, but the signs of fighting are still fresh.
In the southern city of Ashdod, staff at the Pashosh kindergarten, which was hit by a rocket, removed shrapnel from the walls and sliding walls before the students arrived.
We are a bit scared but excited, said Ronit Bart, a resident of Kibbutz Saad and an English teacher there.
Many children in our area urgently need a return to a routine.
Her 11-year-old daughter Shani Bart said it felt "a bit weird" to suddenly go back to school.
These were difficult times and we didn't leave the house at all, she said.
President Reuven Rivlin visited the kibbutz near the Gaza border to offer his support.

Until a ceasefire interrupted the war last week, thousands of residents of border communities like Saad remained in their homes or left their homes to move to safer areas farther from Gaza and escape rocket and mortar fire.
Many residents of Nahal Oz, a community near the Gaza border where a 4-year-old boy was killed by a Palestinian mortar shell, are still reluctant to return.
The Education Ministry said about a dozen families had not yet returned.
Their children were temporarily placed in other schools.
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu visited a school in Sderot, a Gaza border town heavily scarred by Palestinian shelling.
He appealed to the children to learn a lot and said "we will make sure you acquire knowledge and provide you with security."
Israel and Hamas agreed last Tuesday to an indefinite ceasefire.

The ceasefire brought an immediate end to the fighting, but important issues remain unresolved, such as Hamas's demand for the lifting of the Israeli-Egyptian blockade of Gaza and the reopening of Gaza's air and sea ports.
Israel is calling for Hamas to be disarmed and for the bodies of two Israeli soldiers killed in the fighting to be handed over.
A new round of indirect talks is expected to begin in Egypt later this month.
The war has killed more than 2,100 Palestinians, three-quarters of them civilians, and at least 494 children, according to Palestinian and UN estimates.
Israel disputes these claims and estimates that at least half of those killed are militants, but has not provided concrete evidence for this information.
On the Israeli side, 66 soldiers and six civilians, including a Thai worker, were killed.
Hamas and other Gaza militants fired 4,591 rockets and mortar shells at Israeli cities during the fighting, most in the south of the country.
Meanwhile, the Israeli military carried out more than 5,000 air and other strikes.
The Israeli attacks damaged or destroyed thousands of homes in Gaza, and some 250,000 people sought refuge in more than 100 UN schools that were converted into temporary shelters.
As tens of thousands of people continue to live in shelters and fighting continues, education authorities postponed the start of the school year last week.

I hope the school will reopen soon so that we can continue to learn, like the children in the world and the Jewish children, said Mohammad Amara, a 13-year-old boy who currently lives in a school in Gaza City.
After election in Saxony: CDU vice-president Strobl questions NPD ban procedure
In view of the NPD's loss of votes in Saxony, CDU Federal Vice President Thomas Strobl has called for an end to the current NPD ban proceedings before the Federal Constitutional Court.
Berlin - According to CDU Vice President Thomas Strobl, the ongoing prohibition proceedings against the NPD before the Federal Constitutional Court should come to an end.
The NPD is doing worse than last time, Strobl, who is also head of the CDU in Baden-Württemberg, told the "Leipziger Volkszeitung."
This is a welcome development in the right direction and one that leads me to the conclusion that the NPD is being fought politically and not before the Constitutional Court.
The NPD narrowly missed the five percent threshold in Sunday's vote.
A first attempt to ban the far-right party failed in 2003, because the Federal Constitution at that time also had informants at the top of the NPD.
In December 2013, after a long period of preparation, the Federal Council submitted a new application in Karlsruhe.
The Federal Government and the Bundestag did not join in.
Harburg: Tents for new refugees
Refugees are now being housed in tents at Neuländer Platz.
The central reception centre for refugees in Harburg is bursting at the seams.
Now the Home Office has had three Red Cross tents erected next to it.
The district politicians were only informed shortly beforehand - they are not very enthusiastic.

These Hauruck actions further stir up reservations of the citizens and give the district politicians no possibility to participate constructively in the humane accommodation of refugees, says for example Britta Herrmann, parliamentary group leader of the Greens in the Harburg district assembly.
Her party is demanding that the Harburg district administration make currently unused houses available for housing.
96 refugees can be accommodated in the three tents.
Reasons for the overcrowding in initial admissions are the rush of people seeking help - and the fact that the authorities cannot provide enough places in follow-up facilities.
Many refugees therefore stay longer than the regular three months.
House prices have experienced their biggest winter rise in seven years, a widely watched index shows.
The RP Data CoreLogic Hedonic Home Value Index for homes in the Australian capital rose 1.1 per cent in August, RP data showed on Monday.
The increase brings the total increase in June, July and August to 4.2 percent, the biggest increase in the winter months since 2007.
Annual price growth was 10.9 per cent, more than double the increase in the 12 months to August 2013, but the increases were not spread evenly across the country.
RP Data's head of research Tim Lawless said Sydney and Melbourne were driving a two-tier market.
Figures from RP Data show house prices rose 16.1 per cent in Sydney last year, compared with 11.7 per cent in Melbourne.
The following markets are Adelaide, Brisbane and Darwin, where prices rose by an average of five and six per cent respectively.
At the other end of the scale is Canberra, which has been hit hard by government spending cuts, with prices up just 1.4 per cent over the year.
Mr Lawless said that with spring now upon us, there would be a rise in the number of properties for sale over the next few months, which would put the market "to a real test."

If you look at the persistently high rate of auction prices, a generally fast selling rate and the persistently low interest rate environment, it is likely that home prices will continue to rise over the next three months, he said.

This is not the style of the college, the statement said.

The extension of the narrow road up to the castle, which is necessary for the entrance, is also less dramatic than feared by the Medaus.

There is no parking at all, because, as with other public parking lots, this can now be solved intelligently.

According to the university president, the Bergwichtel nursery, which is located on the premises and would lead along the driveway to the parking deck in front of their front door, "will not be affected."

Accordingly, the access road for the new parking deck will not lead via the campus and Friedrich-Streib-Straße as before, but via Medau-Berg.
This would mean that the narrow road would have to be extended to two lanes over a length of about one kilometre.
According to projections of the Medaus, the traffic in the park of Hohenfels Castle would increase tenfold.
There is talk of about 2000 vehicles a day.
The city has so far declined to comment on the project.
Glandorf retires from national handball team
Holger Glandorf will no longer play for the DHB team.
The 31-year-old from the Bundesliga club SG Flensburg-Handewitt cited above all health problems for this decision.
The decision has not been easy for me, it has matured over several months.
It is time for me to listen to the signals of my body and end my career in the national team, "the 2007 world champion said on his Facebook page.
He is retiring from international football with a record of 167 caps and 576 goals for Germany.

Due to the fact that the powerful right back wants to chase goals for the Champions League winner from Flensburg for a few more years, he is no longer available to the new national coach Dagur Sigurdsson.
Glandorf had a "long and good conversation" with the Icelander, who will announce his squad for Tuesday's internationals against Switzerland.
His ideas and approaches have inspired me just as much as they will inspire my long-time teammates and my successors.
But I want to be healthy for my club for the next few years as well, which requires longer regeneration breaks, which the current double load does not allow.
The left-hander had feared his career was over in 2012 after suffering a heel infection.
Due to Achilles tendon problems, he had been treated by team doctors of the German Handball Federation (DHB) with a cortisone injection, which later triggered a severe inflammation.
An emergency operation and two further procedures followed.
Then Glandorf announced a lawsuit against the team doctor, and the dispute ended with a settlement.
Twelve years as a professional and 11 years as a national team player have passed without a trace.
I have some health issues that I can no longer ignore.
After the three infection-related foot surgeries that took place at short intervals in 2012, I never really got my blood pressure under control.
Then there are some other wear-related complaints.
Already at the beginning of the year I realized that I can control my head but not deceive my body, "Glandorf explained in an interview to the magazine" Handball Time. "
He would only be available for a comeback in an absolute emergency.
'When everyone is pulling strings, I'm always ready to talk, 'the father-of-two told the magazine.
However, I can count the years in which I can still play handball on one hand.
I must also say that after my long stay in hospital in 2012, I also became quite humble in terms of my health.
After my career, I want to be able to walk at least somewhat straight.
In addition to winning the World Cup in 2007 and the Champions League in 2014, he also won the EHF Cup in 2008 (HSG Nordhorn) and 2010 (TBV Lemgo).
He also won the European Cup Winners' Cup with Flensburg in 2012.
German economy shrank 0.2 percent in spring
Crises around the world slowed the German economy in the second quarter.
Gross domestic product fell by 0.2 per cent from April to the end of June 2014 compared with the previous quarter.
This was reported by the Federal Statistical Office, thus confirming provisional calculations.
Consumption alone boosted the economy in the spring, while investment fell.
Foreign trade also slowed the economy.
Thanks to the strong start to the year, overall GDP for the first half of the year is up 0.8 percent compared to the second half of 2013.

The castle town of Horstmar experienced an invasion of Dutch "Fietzenfahrer" on Sunday.
The largest cycling federation in the Netherlands, NTFU, organised the so-called "Münsterlande-Mooiste."
This is the largest cycling tour across Münsterland, the cyclists "paradise near the Netherlands.

This tour was advertised in various trade journals.

The route, which was advertised for three different categories, continued towards Herrenholz via Schöppinger Berg towards Coesfeld and via Havixbeck and Billerbeck back to Horstmar.

On routes of 95 kilometres with 1175 metres of altitude difference, 120 kilometres with 1475 metres of altitude difference and 145 kilometres with 1775 metres of altitude difference, the cyclists proved their good condition.
They were fed on the way in Havixbeck and Billerbeck.
Main organiser Jos ter Huerne and deputy mayor Heinz Lölfing were very pleased with the success of this cycling event.
We are satisfied and it was a nice experience for all involved.

Leonidas asked into the gladiatorial arena
Not only the gladiators stood ankle deep in the mud at the first Rheinbacher Römertag in the amusement park.

But the attraction of the event was strong enough to attract well over 1000 visitors yesterday, who braved the rain showers and the autumnal cold and were completely enthralled by the historic spectacle.
There was a colourful round dance of representations, performances, games, exhibits and information about the Roman period and its significance for the Rhineland.

The main attraction of the day was undoubtedly the martial force of the gladiator school "Amor Mortis," who used every rain break to demonstrate their robust martial arts in the arena prepared with soft sand.
Gladiator owner "Leonidas" proved to be a humorous and knowledgeable presenter and one by one sent his men into the ring for heroic duels in various gladiatorial genres.
First it was the turn of the "provocators" with rectangular shield and short sword as well as leg splint on the left leg and arm splint on the right arm.
This was followed by the "Essedarii" with breastplate, short sword and throwing plant as well as an iron gladiator helmet, leg and arm guard.
Particularly impressive was the performance of "Retiarius," who took on the "Secutor" with a cast net, trident and dagger and after a short fight pushed the boy to the ground.
Then the swords crashed metallic against each other, the shields rattled and the worm plants flew buzzing through the arena, so that one could fear for the health of the gladiators.
But the imposing "Summa Rudis," the muscular referee, always kept an eye on them.

We wanted to revive Roman everyday life and bring the culture of the Roman era to life, Lorenz Euskirchen, chairman of the organizer "Freundeskreis Römerkanal," explained the intention behind the spectacle.
After two years of preparation, the amusement park became for one day an "Oppidum Romanum," a Roman city, as Deputy Mayor Claus Wehage stated in his greeting.
After all, the Romans brought not only war and conquest to our region, but also the Roman culture and numerous buildings that we still admire today.
Remains of this were also to be admired during the Roman Day, such as the "aqueduct marble" from the eleven-metre-high and 1400-metre-long Roman Canal Bridge, which once stood near Lüftelberg.
The Frontinus Society contrasted the water and energy supply then and now, and Managing Director Petra Fricke knew: "We are still benefiting from the knowledge of that time."
This is also confirmed by graduate surveyor Ralph Heiliger from "IngenieurteamZwei" from Rheinbach, who presented surveying instruments from the Romans such as Chorobat, Groma or Dioptra.
The Roman villa in Blankenheim presented sketches and models from the excavations in 1894 as well as bricks from the original hypocaust, the warm air heating that once heated the Roman villa.
The footprints left by wolf and fox in the clay footsteps two millennia ago, before they were burned, are also impressive.
In 2011, the Office for the Preservation of Soil Monuments at the Rhineland Regional Office excavated the remains of a Roman villa in the North Industrial Park in Rheinbach.
Walls of an outbuilding with a kiln for drying grain and malting were found.
The building probably belonged to a Villa Rustica, an agricultural estate, explained archaeologist Dr. Jennifer Morscheiser.
She presented a number of finds from these excavations in a glass display case, including a large plate, several fine glass vessels and parts of a dainty necklace.
According to Morscheiser, the villa probably existed from the first to the fourth century AD, until the Germanic invasion of the then Roman Rhineland.
In addition, the children were occupied with the Roman windmill game, similar to today's windmill game, or they wrote their names on wax tablets with metal pens, as the Roman pupils once did.

At the stand of the Römerthermen Zülpich the children were allowed to lay mosaics themselves, make glass mosaics at the stand of the Glasmuseum Rheinbach and operate a heavy wheat mill made of stone at the stand of the Naturzentrum Eifel Nettersheim to grind the flour for a flatbread or a muesli.

The visitors drove through the amusement park in a faithfully reconstructed Roman coach drawn by two cold-blooded men, passing by the impressive stand of the Municipal High School, which presented the results of its "Roman Project Weeks."

With a Roman Week from 13 to 21 September, the municipality of Wachtberg will also be involved in the Roman Year 2014, which has been proclaimed throughout the Rhineland and is intended to commemorate the death of Emperor Augustus 2000 years ago.

Together with the local and historical associations as well as the Wachtberger Wander-Verein, the Partnerschaftsverein and the Laienspielkreis Oberbachem, thematic hikes, a lecture, cooking evenings as well as guided tours for school classes are offered and remind of Wachtberg's Roman past.

For example, a Roman legionary will talk about his work on the draughty Wachtberg, plants will be presented as living monuments from Roman times and a witty lesson in international understanding between a group of Wachtberg "Teutons" and Romans who moved in.
The Adendorf Primary School is dedicating a project week to the Roman theme.
With the Roman Week, the numerous traces of the Romans in Wachtberg, which are often no longer visible at first glance, are to be experienced again.
In the Wachtberg town hall, a small presentation will commemorate the discovery of the Berkumer Matron Sanctuary in 1879.
Ebola: epidemic weighs on West Africa's economy
The Ebola epidemic in West Africa is also a major blow to the economy.
Markets are orphaned - and international companies are keeping their distance.
The devastating Ebola epidemic has dealt a major blow to West Africa's economy.
The crops are rotting in the fields, the mines are deserted and the markets are orphaned - the virus has hit the region hard.
Some international companies are also already distancing themselves.
The Ebola epidemic is not only a medical crisis, but also an economic one, says Donald Kaberuka, head of the African Development Bank.
Liberia is hardest hit
It's a total disaster, we're losing a lot of money, said Alhaji Bamogo, who sells clothes in Liberia's second-largest market, Monrovia.
Only those who want to buy food or something to disinfect against Ebola can enter the market.
Liberia has been hardest hit by the virus, with more than 600 people killed by the fever here alone.
Recently, health officials said the disease had spread to every corner of the country.
The virus has also spread to Guinea, Sierra Leone and Nigeria.
In total, more than 1,500 people have already died and thousands more have been infected.
Foreign firms are withdrawing staff
Across resource-rich countries, companies are suspending operations.
Foreign companies such as the steel group Arcelor Mittal are withdrawing their employees and several international airlines are no longer flying to the affected regions.
Local traders and farmers are also reacting: only a few merchants are still leaving their hometowns to procure supplies.
In some quarantined areas of Sierra Leone and Liberia, cocoa and coffee beans, which are important for export, are rotting in the fields.
The farmers do not dare to leave their homes for the harvest.
Food is running out
People will travel less and less, says Phillipe De Vreyer, a Parisian expert on the West African economy.
For example, the man who normally goes to the market and sells his vegetables prefers to stay at home.
The population is therefore feeling the consequences of the epidemic directly and urgently: food is becoming scarce.
In the markets, stocks of staples such as rice are dwindling.
At the same time, the region, which is heavily dependent on international companies, is in danger of damaging its image - with far-reaching consequences.
The biggest danger is that international companies generally avoid the area for a long time, says Philippe Hugon of the French think tank Iris.
The decisive factor is how far and for how long the virus will continue to spread.
Investors may get the impression "that it is dangerous to live and invest in Guinea, Sierra Leone and Liberia," Hugon warns.
The disease is also straining states' stretched budgets
The disease is also putting a strain on the already stretched state budgets of the affected states.
Moody's, the credit rating agency, fears that their budgets will be severely strained by high spending on the health care system and the worsening economy.
The African Development Bank has already pledged 60 million dollars (45 million euros) to help the health systems of the affected countries.
The effects are already being felt in Nigeria, where few Ebola cases have been diagnosed so far.
The oil-rich region in the southern Niger Delta has not yet been affected.
But elsewhere, many people are already staying at home for fear of contagion.
Reservations in hotels are also falling significantly.

After 2700 hours of work, Father Strasser gave the church blessing for the new trenches on 8 May 1988.

Genetic disorder often misdiagnosed
A British woman says she thought she was going to die as a result of a misdiagnosis over many years.
Karin Rodgers spent most of her youth believing that she had only a few years left to live after being diagnosed with another disease.
She was indeed suffering from Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (CMT) - a group of inherited disorders that damage the nerves outside the brain and spinal cord.
Charity CMT UK said misdiagnosis is a common problem in people with CMT because so little is known about the disease.
Around 23,000 people in the UK are thought to suffer from CMT, which can lead to motor disorders such as muscle weakness, unsteady gait and curved toes.
Sufferers also suffer from numbness or pain. The disease is incurable and progressive, which means that the symptoms get worse over time.
When Rodgers was 13, she believed she was suffering from Friedreich ataxia (FA) - a disease with a very poor chance of survival.
Rodgers thought she would be in a wheelchair before she turned 18 and die before her 30th birthday.
The mother-of-two, who is now 51, said: 'As a child I knew I couldn't do the same as the others.
I kept falling down and it all took me longer.
I could never roller-skate or skateboard with the other kids and was often teased at school because of the way I walked and ran.

Rodgers said that at the age of 13, after several operations to relieve her Achilles tendons and stretch her feet, she looked at her medical records when her doctor left the room and read that she was suffering from FA.
I felt guilty because I had been curious, so I didn't tell anyone, but I went home, looked for the disease in the library and wrote to the FA Society, she said.
When I received the answer, I was shocked and panicked terribly.
I thought I was going to be in a wheelchair at 18 and die at 25 and slowly lose all my skills in between.
I did it all on my own and planned my own funeral.
She said that when she turned 17, she realized that her abilities had not diminished as much as she had imagined, and consulted her doctor.
He just got up and gave me a hug and said, "My dear, I don't think you have that, otherwise you'd be in a wheelchair by now."
I think you have something far less life-threatening.
After some genetic tests she was diagnosed with CMT.
When he told me what CMT was, I felt like I was a winner, she said.
Charity CMT UK has launched a CMT Awareness Month to raise awareness of the disease.

Tax burden on Washington area businessmen rises as economy recovers
A recovery in the economy means more customers, more sales and new jobs.
It also means higher taxes.
State and local corporate tax filings rose slightly last year as the economic recovery accelerated, according to a newly released study last week, and Washington-area firms were no exception.
Companies in the District, Maryland and Virginia collectively paid $27.6 billion to state and local agencies in fiscal 2013, up 3.8 percent from 2012 revenue of $26.6 billion.

The state and local corporate tax burden rose 4.3 percent last year to $671 billion, up from 3.9 percent the year before, and it was the third consecutive year of growth after several years of declining revenue in 2009 and 2010.
State taxes rose more than local taxes, by 4.3 percent, according to the study, which was conducted by Ernst & Young with the Center for State Taxation, a tax policy group.
More than half of the District's tax revenue, 56 percent, comes from corporate taxes, while 36 percent of Maryland's revenue comes from corporations.
Virginia has the lowest corporate tax revenue at 28 percent.

Much of the increase in tax revenue is due to a recovery in corporate real estate values, the researchers say, leading to a 3.7 percent increase in property taxes this year after three consecutive years of growth rates of less than 1 percent.
While much of those gains came from big states like California, New York and Texas, the pattern seems to apply to the Washington area as well.

Companies in the District, Maryland and Virginia collectively paid more than $10 billion in state and local property taxes last year, compared with $9.6 billion in 2012 - a 4.2 percent increase over the course of a year.
But the apparent recovery in real estate values is not as effective in raising state and local tax revenue in Maryland, where property taxes account for just over one-fifth of corporate tax returns.
Companies in Virginia and D.C. pay nearly half of their state and local taxes in the form of property taxes.

In Maryland, a lot of real estate, especially in the D.C. tax area, is either owned by the government or by nonprofits that don't pay real estate taxes, said Douglas Lindholm, executive director of the Center on State Taxation.
Maryland, for example, is forced to rely much more on income taxes to provide the same services that other states provide.
The recent recovery in corporate tax receipts cannot be attributed solely to the recovery in the housing market.
Corporate revenues also appear to be recovering, the data showed.
Businesses in the region reported income taxes at state organizations of $2.3 billion, up from $2.1 billion in 2012.
Maryland took in $1 billion in corporate income taxes, the highest amount in the region.
While the trend is in the same direction, the local tax burden on businesses is not rising evenly in all three places.
The rate of increase in the District was 4.3 percent, in line with the national average, while the increase in Maryland was much higher, 4.9 percent.
Only Virginia reported a below-average tax rate of 4.1 percent.
Virginia has by far the lowest corporate income taxes in all three jurisdictions, at 6 percent (all three have fixed corporate tax rates).
Maryland's corporate tax rate is 8.25 percent and the District's is a relatively high 9.975 percent.
A similar study by the US Chamber of Commerce earlier this year showed that Virginia has lower state and local corporate taxes and a better overall tax climate than Maryland.
The study did not examine the District.
Despite the advantages, Virginia is under pressure from its southern neighbor.
North Carolina passed legislation this year to cut its corporate tax rate from 6.9 percent to 6 percent, the same rate as Virginia, and the rate will drop to 5 percent next year.
If the state continues to meet its income targets next year, the law could reduce the state's corporate income tax rate to 3 percent by 2017.
Meanwhile, small businesses in the Washington area appear to be doing better, and are paying more state and local taxes, according to the latest study.

Corporate taxes paid as personal income taxes by small business owners - a transitional structure under which most small businesses are organized - in the District, Maryland, and Virginia rose 20 percent last year to $2.4 billion, a much faster rate of growth than overall corporate taxes.

The researchers say the trend and rise in corporate taxes across the country is likely to continue this year, with overall sales tax receipts for state and local governments up 6.2 percent in the first three quarters of 2014 compared with the same period last year.
Still, the Washington area could lag behind if the federal government's spending cuts affect the region's labor market.

After weeks of tug-of-war, Italy's prime minister and current EU president, Matteo Renzi, pushed through the nomination of his foreign minister, Federica Mogherini, as head of EU foreign policy at last week's special EU summit, succeeding Britain's Catherine Ashton.

Renzi, according to the pro-government daily La Repubblica, sees the appointment of Mogherini, who is also seen as a favorite in the government team, as strengthening the position of the Social Democrats and his own in the EU.
He also expects this to give a boost to his "reform package" in Italy.
Last but not least, Renzi hopes that this will also calm the left-wing party base, which has repeatedly rebelled against him, because Mogherini is associated with him - albeit in a more moderate way.

According to the prevailing opinion in Rome, a political balance will be struck between the conservative representatives with Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker and Donald Tusk, the Polish nominee for Council President.
The EU's chief diplomat will also serve as a deputy to Commission President Juncker.
The pending approval of the EU Parliament is considered certain.

Otherwise, President Giorgio Napolitano would hardly have called the nomination of the 41-year-old politician from the ruling Democratic Party (PD) an "important recognition" of Italy's role in the EU.
La Repubblica is optimistic that Mogherini, who has held senior party posts for nearly two decades and is known for her ambition, will rise to the "enormous challenges."
Born in Rome, she is married and has two daughters.

The political scientist began her party career in 1996 in the youth organisation of the then Democratici di Sinistra (Left Democrats), which merged with the Catholic Centre Party Margherita in 2008 to form today's Social Democratic PD.
In 1999, Mogherini became Vice-President of the European Community Organisation of Socialist Youth for three years.
With the election in 2001 to the Party Council of the Left Democrats, she entered high party politics, working in the foreign policy department, of which she soon became head.

She occupied traditional focuses of Italian foreign policy such as the Middle East, became known through studies on the NATO mission in Afghanistan, in which Italy is involved with a contingent of troops, and maintained contacts with the Social Democrats in Europe and the Democrats in the USA.
Since 2008, she has been a member of the Chamber of Deputies, where she is an expert on defence and European and international affairs.
When Renzi became prime minister in February 2014, he appointed Mogherini as his foreign minister.

If the PD today has a better relationship with the strong peace movement in the country, which contributed to the party's more than 40% vote in the EU elections in May, then Federica Mogherini will have a share, as is noted in PD circles.
The accusations in Brussels that the new EU High Representative has too little diplomatic experience and therefore lacks substance are countered in the PD.
In Brussels, especially Poland and the Baltic states, Mogherini's suspiciously realistic approach to the crisis in Ukraine is being vilified as a "pro-Russia course."

It is in favour of the South Stream pipeline, operated by the Russian company Gazprom, through which Russian natural gas will be transported directly to southern Europe, bypassing Ukraine, which also serves to secure Italy's energy.
After Renzi took office as EU president in July, Mogherini made her first state visit to Moscow.
Photos showing her shaking hands with Putin were met with outrage in Brussels, as was inviting the Kremlin chief to a Milan economic summit in October.

The Socialists in France should "shut up and put France in order," said Francois Hollande's main ally.
Mr Valls called on the deeply divided left to show "their love" for the controversial socialist president, whose cabinet reshuffle has met with disapproval from the vast majority of French people.
The President deserves everyone's respect, he deserves our loyalty, he deserves our support.
It is our duty to stay by his side, he said to loud applause.

In a reassuring gesture, the prime minister insisted that his government would not challenge France's controversial 35-hour week, despite fierce calls for it to be relaxed by Emmanuel Macron, the new economy minister.
On Saturday, Mr Hollande urged his fellow Socialists to show "unity" with the government.

But Christiane Taubira, the justice minister, threw a spanner in the works by appearing at a meeting of renegade Socialist MPs and criticizing the Socialist Party for taking away French "faith in their future."
Marine Le Pen, the far-right leader of the National Front, mocked the Socialists "constant infighting, saying she could not imagine that the new Valls government would last more than a few months.
Francois Hollande is the emperor without clothes, but Prince Manuel Valls has none either, they are forced to form a new government when the old one has not even survived a summer.
And the new one won't survive the autumn or winter either, Miss Le Pen told supporters.
She repeated her party's call for parliament to be dissolved, saying she was confident of winning early elections and was ready to govern.
France's ruling party suffered defeat in local elections in March, and the right-wing National Front was ahead in May's EU elections.

A poll in the Sunday newspaper Journal du Dimanche found that 76 percent of French people believe the Socialist Party is in danger of splitting into several rival factions before Hollande's term ends in 2017.

Pascal Perrineau, a political scientist at Sciences Po University, warned that the French would quickly lose patience if the new Socialist government failed to improve the economy and record unemployment.
There is a small window of opportunity, but public opinion needs to feel quickly that things are changing, he warned.
Otherwise, the situation could deteriorate further.
Norwegian Cruise nears $3bn deal with Prestige Cruises

Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings Ltd NCHL.O, the world's third-largest cruise operator, is in advanced negotiations to acquire rival Prestige Cruises International Inc for about $3 billion, according to industry insiders.

A deal would give Norwegian Cruise, a company with a market value of $6.8 billion, access to Prestige Cruises' luxury cruise ships and its wealthy clientele, while competing with larger rivals such as Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd (RCL.N) and Carnival Corp (CCL.N).
An agreement could be announced as early as this week, the sources said on Sunday, warning that the talks could also end inconclusively.
The owner of Prestige Cruises, private equity firm Apollo Global Management LLC (APO.N), also owns a 20 percent stake in Norwegian Cruise.
The sources asked to remain anonymous because the negotiations are not public.
Representatives for Norwegian Cruise and Prestige Cruises did not respond to requests for comment, while a spokesman for Apollo declined to comment.
Miami-based Norwegian Cruise operates 13 cruise ships on routes between North America, the Mediterranean, the Baltic Sea, Central America and the Caribbean.
Its revenue in 2013 was $2.57 billion, up 13 percent from 2012.

Prestige Cruises, also based in Miami, operates under the brand names Oceania and Regent, which together operate eight cruise ships on routes to Scandinavia, Russia, the Mediterranean, North America, Asia, Africa and South America.
It reported revenue for 2013 of $1.2 billion, an increase of 6 percent over the previous year.
The cruise industry totals about $29 billion and is expected to grow in the next few years as the middle class strengthens in emerging markets such as China and India.
Companies are trying to position themselves as the best choice among cruise operators for these new customers.
Prestige Cruises filed for IPO with US regulators in January 2014.
Apollo has been the majority shareholder in the company since an $850 million deal in 2007.

Norwegian Cruise in its current form was formed in 2000 through a merger with a cruise operator owned by Genting Bhd (GENT.KL), a leisure and casino conglomerate controlled by Malaysian billionaire Lim Kok Thay.
Apollo invested $1 billion in Norwegian Cruise in 2008.
Norwegian Cruise went public in January 2013.
Genting held a 28 percent stake in the company at the end of June, Apollo a 20 percent stake and private equity firm TPG Capital LP an 8 percent stake, according to regulatory filings.

Carnival, Royal Caribbean Cruises and Norwegian Cruise together hold 82 percent of the passenger capacity of American cruise ships, according to the initial public offering documents for Prestige Cruises.

Putin urges Kiev to start 'statehood talks' with eastern Ukraine

Russian President Vladimir Putin demanded on Sunday that the Ukrainian government cease fighting separatists in the east of the country and immediately begin negotiations on the "statehood" of the breakaway region, according to Russian media reports.

His spokesman, Dmitry Peskov, later clarified that Putin did not mean that the separatist-controlled territory of eastern Ukraine would become part of Russia, but that its status vis-à-vis Ukraine would have to be redefined to give the Russian-speaking region the power to represent its rights and interests.

Putin's call for the Kiev government to negotiate on an equal footing with the pro-Russian insurgents, however, fits with the strategy he seems to have pursued since the riots began five months ago: helping the separatists seize territory and putting pressure on the Ukrainian government to allow the newly proclaimed Novorossiya region de facto independence for an alliance with Russia rather than the West.

In an interview with state-run Channel One television, Putin condemned Ukraine's military campaign to recapture separatist-held territories in the eastern regions of Donetsk and Luhansk, which were captured in March and April after Moscow annexed Ukraine's Crimean peninsula on March 18.
The Kremlin and the separatists have recently called the captured territory "Novorossiya" or "Novorossiya," a term reminiscent of the pre-revolutionary heyday of the Russian empire.

Putin pointed out that all those who hope for early peace talks as Ukrainian politicians campaign for the October 26 elections and as government groups attack civilian communities in separatist-held areas are "trapped in their illusions," Itar-Tass reported.

We must immediately start detailed talks, not only on technical issues, but also on the political organisation of society and the state status of south-east Ukraine, in order to safeguard the interests of the people living there, he said.

Peskov said Putin's reference to statehood must be seen in the context of the greater autonomy that Kiev's leaders have been discussing for months to allay fears in Russian-speaking areas that their cultural and linguistic rights are under threat.
Only the Ukrainian government can grant the eastern regions the necessary autonomy, Peskov said.
This is not about negotiations between Ukraine and Russia, Peskov said, "because this is not about a conflict between Russia and Ukraine, but about an internal conflict in Ukraine."

The Kremlin spokesman's clarification to correct the "misinterpretation" of Putin's remarks underscored Russia's leadership in dealing with the separatist rebellion in the east, as opposed to the outright annexation of Crimea, where the majority of its 2 million residents are ethnic Russians.

Moscow would have far greater difficulty annexing the Donetsk and Luhansk regions of eastern Ukraine, because most of its 6.5 million inhabitants are not Russians, and pre-conflict polls showed a broad majority in favor of remaining in Ukraine.

Autonomy, raised by Russian diplomats at international forums, would give Ukraine's regional governments authority to negotiate their own trade agreements and external relations, effectively giving the Kremlin control over an area linking Russian territory to Crimea.
The Black Sea peninsula, annexed five months ago, is the home port for most of Russia's navy, as well as an important commercial port and historic coastal region.
The region between the Rostov region in Russia and Crimea is also rich in mines, factories and foundries that produce important components for the Russian military.

Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko, in his inauguration speech on 7 June, suggested that Ukrainian legislation - after new elections - should consider amendments to the constitution that would give the respective territories greater control over their finances and the status of languages.
But his idea of autonomy appears to be in sharp contrast to those of the Kremlin and separatist rebels, whom Moscow accuses of arming and inciting.

Putin's latest call for Kiev to negotiate on an equal footing with the separatist leaders came after another rebel advance last week, after Russian troops and tanks entered eastern Ukraine via the previously peaceful region along the Sea of Azov.

The Russian-backed separatists seized control of Novoazovsk in a coup that Ukrainian security officials fear is the first step in a campaign to seize the strategic coastal region stretching as far as Crimea.
As a result, massive civil and military preparations have begun to fortify Mariupol, a steel port of 500,000 inhabitants located between Novoazovsk and the narrow access to the Crimean peninsula.
Poroshenko spoke Saturday at a meeting of EU leaders in Brussels, urging action to prevent further Russian aggression against Ukraine, a former Soviet republic that has been independent for 23 years.
We are close to a point where there is no turning back, Poroshenko warned.
Thousands of foreign troops and hundreds of foreign tanks are now on Ukrainian territory.

The EU summit did not decide on any concrete actions, the leadership demanded the drafting of further sanctions against Russia, which should come into force in the event of an unspecified escalation of the Ukrainian crisis.

Ukrainian soldiers were forced to withdraw from their positions in Ilovaysk after two Russian columns of tanks and 1,000 soldiers entered the Donetsk region last week to support the besieged separatists, Colonel Andriy Lysenko, spokesman for Ukraine's National Security and Defense Council, told reporters in Kiev on Saturday.

The first 63 Ukrainian soldiers believed to have been trapped by the Russian incursion into Ilovaysk were exchanged on Sunday for 10 Russian paratroopers captured on Ukrainian territory a week ago, Lysenko said on Sunday.

Cyclists, joggers and hikers took part in the 8th cycling event on the Großer Feldberg yesterday, supporting the association "Hilfe für krebskranke Kinder" (Help for children with cancer).
The tour, which was an ordeal for some, was an easy workout for others.
But everyone agreed on one thing: it was fun.
Thomas Studanski must have slept well last night.
For the first time in his life, the head of the Oberursel brewery rode his bike up the Feldberg yesterday.
For a good cause.

He can easily put the little muscle soreness away, especially since the participation in the 8th Cycling on the Großer Feldberg for the benefit of the association "Hilfe für krebskranke Kinder" (Frankfurt) brought him personally a valuable insight.
A great thing.
I know now that I can do it - great!
Little break on the way in the applause curve?
Nope, if I had stopped once, it would have been over...

Like Thomas Studanski, who sits for the CDU in the Upper Ursel city parliament, many of the 718 participants struggled to get up in the early morning dew yesterday and came close to exhaustion, but happy on the plateau.
Others, on the other hand, found it easier to overcome the eleven-kilometre stretch between Hohemark and Feldberg.
Norman Dießner, for example.

The all-red Green politician from the district council - red dress, red bike - made a bit of an understatement at the start ("A lot of professionals, arriving is the goal!"), but then proved to be half a pro on the mountain and crossed the finish line after 45 minutes without breathing.
He, too, rode the course in one go, as did Nina Kuhn, press officer of the town of Oberursel, who set off together with Frank Grüneisen.
For the two triathletes, "Feldberg cycling" was not necessarily a sporting challenge: "This is about charity, we would love to be part of it - we would have taken a ride today anyway," says Kuhn.
On the way they met Paul Wenzel from Oberreifenberg.
The boy (12) had gone down to Oberursel in the morning in order to get back on his feet immediately afterwards.
Florian Zierz from Frankfurt got into the saddle at 9am, "made" the Feldberg twice, and then rode home with a lot of fun.
Fried Toni also had fun.
For the head of the cult kiosk in Oberursel, cycling tours over the Feldberg are simply part of it.
He had set his sights on 40 minutes on his 6.5-kilo road bike.
A crazy event.
For this purpose - I am happy to be there, "said Andreas Balzke.
The well-trained Mainz rider says he is an "ambitious racing cyclist."
He has to be, because he was on the "fixie bike," which are also racing bikes, but without gears...

Not only the 20 hikers, who climbed over the White Wall and the Fuchstanz to the summit, but also a jogger, who pulled a car tyre with weights behind him on a cord, proved that it was easy to climb even without a bike.

Mountain rescue doctor Professor Volker Lischke, who ensured safety with his team, equipped with a four-wheel-drive bully and quad bike, said: "I know him from Frankfurt, who trains for a special sled track, but he just pulls the sled himself." So the man is in a sense his own sled dog.
The 718 participants - more than ever before - had been sent out on the course in groups in the morning.
The walkers first arrived at 9.30am.
The first cyclists and runners followed at 10am.
Five minutes later, the first mountain bikers set off.
Bent Hansen, chairman of the association "Radeln auf den Großen Feldberg," gave the starting commands and wished the participants a nice trip.
For next year he hopes that it will be possible to close the route up to the Feldberg for the safety of the participants.
